name: 吳昭正
objective:
This class starts from the review of random process to the topics of detection and estimation theories. The following is a rough description of the material covered in this class.
1. Bayesian hypothesis testing
2. Minimax hypothesis testing
3. Neyman-Pearson and composite hypothesis testing
4. Bayesian parameter estimation 
5. Nonrandom parameter estimation
6. Maximum likelihood estimation
7. Kalman filtering
schedule:
Week 1(2/24). Introduction
Week 2(3/2). Review of Random Variables (I)
Week 3(3/9). Hypothesis Testing 
Week 4(3/16). Bayesian Hypothesis Testing (I)
Week 5(3/23). Bayesian Hypothesis Testing (II)
Week 6(3/30). Minimax Hypothesis Testing  
Week 7(4/6). Holiday
Week 8(4/13). Neyman-Pearson and Composite Hypothesis Testing  
Week 9(4/20). Detection of Deterministic Signals
Week 10(4/27). Midterm
Week 11(5/4). Bayesian Parameter Estimation 
Week 12(5/11). Nonrandom Parameter Estimation
Week 13(5/18). Maximum Likelihood Estimation (I)
Week 14(5/25). Maximum Likelihood Estimation (II) 
Week 15(6/1). General Bayesian Estimation  
Week 16(6/8). Linear Bayesian Estimation 
Week 17(6/15). Kalman Filtering
Week 18(6/22). Final Term
scorePolicy:
1. Midterm 30%
2. Final Term 30%
3. Term Paper 40%
4. Class Participation 10%
materials:
Required text: 
1. An Introduction to Signal Detection and Estimation, H. Vincent Poor, 1998.
Optional text: 
1. Fundamentals of Statistical Signal Processing Volume I: Estimation Theory, Steven M. Kay,  2001.
2. Fundamentals of Statistical Signal Processing Volume II: Detection Theory, Steven M. Kay,  2001.
3. Probability and Stochastic Processes: A Friendly Introduction for Electrical and Computer Engineers, Roy D. Yates and David Goodman, 2004.
4. Random Signals: Detection, Estimation and Data Analysis, K. Sam Shanmugan and Arthur M. Breipohl, 1988.
5. Detection of Signals in Noise, Robert N. McDonough and A. D. Whalen, 1995.
